captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

JF MUSIAL: Very few car
companies can claim that

they've been around
for 100 years.
This is one of them--
Aston Martin.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

JF MUSIAL: Built on the site
of an old RAF Air Base in

Gaydon, the new home for Aston
Martin was built in 2003 and

is one of the top three
best-looking car
factories in the world.
What are the other two?

The McLaren Technology Centre,
and of course, Volkswagen's
transparent factory.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

JF MUSIAL: But it's important to
remember that Gaydon is not

where the legacy of Aston
Martin started.

This new modern factory matches
the elegant design of

the cars produced within its
walls, but the company's roots

come from a different
town an hour away.

GRAHAM DARBY: Obviously, the
show room opened May last year
after 11 months development.

The service department's been
here since the mid '60s and

always is part of the
manufacturer itself.

Obviously, the decisions was
made that we should retail
cars as well.

And this is the retail
department of Aston Martin.

So new show room opened,
completely corporate,
beautiful as you could see.

JF MUSIAL: It matches the
same architecture as--
GRAHAM DARBY: Absolutely.

Corporate identity for Aston
Martin to exact standards.
JF MUSIAL: So this is--

GRAHAM DARBY: Modern vehicle
workshop, so we look after all

vehicles from late model DB7
in this workshop through to
new Vanquish and 177.

JF MUSIAL: So these
are customer cars.

GRAHAM DARBY: All of these
are customer cars,
yes, very much so.

Over here is what we call the
flight deck area, which is

vehicles that are finished
ready for handover or
collection from the customers.

In here, we have nine qualified
technicians.

We looked after, last year,
2,600 Aston Martins in a year.
JF MUSIAL: Thats quite a lot.

GRAHAM DARBY: It's a huge
amount, but this is the

biggest Aston Martin technical
facility in the world.

JF MUSIAL: What about in terms
of it's not only just basic

service, but you could
do everything here.
GRAHAM DARBY: Everything on--

if you want something done to
your Aston Martin, as long as

it's safe and it's legal,
we'll do it for you.

At the moment, we have
two Vanquish--

original Vanquish in that we
do manual conversions to.

So we've done over
90 of those now.

JF MUSIAL: That's become
a very big thing--

GRAHAM DARBY: Yes,
very much so.

JF MUSIAL: --in terms of taking
the Vanquishes, which

didn't initially come with
manual transmissions.
GRAHAM DARBY: Nope.

No, it was automatic
transmission, paddle shift.

JF MUSIAL: And so it's
a certified change.

GRAHAM DARBY: Change to
stick shift, yeah.
JF MUSIAL: Interesting.

GRAHAM DARBY: So we got one from
Australia and one from
the Netherlands at the moment.
We're into the 90s now.

And we usually do four
or five a year.

JF MUSIAL: That's
very impressive.

GRAHAM DARBY: And that
keeps coming.

We did two in North
America last year.
JF MUSIAL: Yeah.

Actually, I know someone who
owns a Vanquish in the States,

and he's thinking about doing
just that-- still.
GRAHAM DARBY: You got my card?
[LAUGHTER]

GRAHAM DARBY: In here
is the paint and
body shop, panel show.

So this side is what we call
MET or mechanical.

That's strip and rebuild,
as you can see on
the Rapide over there.

The guys would take and strip
the cars completely.

If there's any panels that
need to be cut out and

replaced, bonded, that
will be done in here.

Then the cars will go through
and be painted.

And then they'll come back out
here after the panels are

polished, and we'll
rebuild it.

So you can see, there's a
pre-war over there, which

we've replaced the rear
end of that car.

Unfortunately, it was rear-ended
in an accident.

That's had front fender,
both rear fenders, and
a rear panel replaced.
JF MUSIAL: So this is pre-war?
GRAHAM DARBY: Yeah.

JF MUSIAL: Where do you
get information on
fixing such a car?

How do you even start
with that?

GRAHAM DARBY: Reference
libraries, speaking with

people who've had the
experience, and knowledge,

especially when it comes to
taking the car apart.

They're relatively easy to come
apart in comparison to
the cars next to it.

When it comes to making the
panels, it's all down to the
craftsmen that work here.

JF MUSIAL: They're actually
doing it themselves and--
GRAHAM DARBY: You'll see.

JF MUSIAL: --looking at
reference photos, pictures--
GRAHAM DARBY: Absolutely.
Absolutely.

JF MUSIAL: --and just taking
it from there.
GRAHAM DARBY: Yeah.
JF MUSIAL: That's incredible.

GRAHAM DARBY: Right-hand drive
to left-hand drive convention.
JF MUSIAL: No way!

GRAHAM DARBY: So changing the
bulkhead for the wiper
spindles and the whitewashes.

JF MUSIAL: That seems
like a lot of work
for not much change.

GRAHAM DARBY: It's down to
the owner's preference.
JF MUSIAL: Understood.
OK.

Well, that shows that
you'll do anything.
GRAHAM DARBY: Absolutely.

JF MUSIAL: Absolutely
anything.

GRAHAM DARBY: And you can see
in here that you've got the

V8, you've got a Rapide S, and
you've got a pre-war, all
parked next to each other.

So it just shows the diversity
that we can do here.

Supercharged Vantage
full-color change.

JF MUSIAL: So people who just
want to have their car color
changed, you'll do it?
GRAHAM DARBY: Yep.

And this owner, we're doing a
full-color change, engine

rebuild, new interior, but we're
also putting into it an

upgraded six-speed automatic
transmission.

So going away from the
original one where we

developed using the same
factory techniques, so

six-speed, automatic
transmission for V8,

two-valve, and supercharged
Vantage.

JF MUSIAL: Correct
me if I'm wrong.

It was initially a four-speed
back then.
GRAHAM DARBY: Correct.
JF MUSIAL: So that's such an--

so you're actually developing
the trans--

you're not developing the
transmission, but you're
adapting it to this car.

GRAHAM DARBY: We've developed
an existing transmission to
fit the vehicle.
JF MUSIAL: Got it.

GRAHAM DARBY: And then made sure
that the valve bodies and
so on are matched to the car.
So we tested it in NADA.
We've tested it in Sweden.

We've tested it in
the Middle East.

So we've gone through the full
test program to make sure that

it's compliant as you would
do a new production model.
JF MUSIAL: Yeah.
It's not just bolting it in.

You're actually going through
the whole procedure and making

sure it's right for
the customer.

GRAHAM DARBY: Well, you
have to match the
gearbox to the car--
JF MUSIAL: Of course.
GRAHAM DARBY: --as well.

JF MUSIAL: I see a a DB2
front-end right over there.

GRAHAM DARBY: You
certainly do.

This is a DB2 body
that we've just--

3/4 of the way through
a restoration.
So we've now blacked the
interior, painted the interior.

The guys are now doing
flat and polish.

Once the paint's perfect,
it'll be
taken down to the chassis.
And I'll show you the chassis.

JF MUSIAL: That's
a big project.

GRAHAM DARBY: So that's
in build.

But no, this is how we work
on every restoration.

Everything is stripped back
to every nut and bolt.

If there's too much corrosion,
or it's not safe or not
serviceable, we'll replace it.
We have to.

And then that's what
you end up with.

As you can see, there's
the nose for it.

And that's been prefitted, as
you can see, with a trim.

Once we're happy with the trim,
that'll be taken off
center way and re-chromed.

JF MUSIAL: And how long of a
project with this thing?

GRAHAM DARBY: Each restoration's
about 14 months.
JF MUSIAL: 14 months.
GRAHAM DARBY: 12 to 14 months.

JF MUSIAL: And that's standard
across any vehicle
for the most part?

GRAHAM DARBY: Pretty
much, yeah.
Pretty much.

It depends on obviously
the base car.

If you've got a car which is
particularly heavily corroded

or the customer wants something
unique in the

specification, then yes, it
may take a little longer.

But we aim to 12 to 14 months
per restoration.

But obviously, at the moment,
we've got a waiting list going
into mid 2014.
So this is the panel shop.

We opened this January this
year, nine guys in here.

We still have all the original
body box, so
V8 two-valve, DB5.

This is what's left
of a DB5 chassis.
JF MUSIAL: Whoa!

GRAHAM DARBY: And
as you can see--
JF MUSIAL: That's not usable.

GRAHAM DARBY: This is
my prime example of
when it's not usable.

You can see that it's
wafer thin.
JF MUSIAL: Yeah, it's just--

GRAHAM DARBY: So we made
him a new one.

JF MUSIAL: That's
a chassis from--

GRAHAM DARBY: That's a DB5
chassis hand built by my team.

JF MUSIAL: And where are
the jigs coming from.

Are you creating
your own jigs?

GRAHAM DARBY: See,
look at all the
measurements on the bulkhead.
JF MUSIAL: Yeah.

GRAHAM DARBY: The guys will mark
out every single part of

the car and dismantle it panel
by panel by panel, taking all
the measurements.
JF MUSIAL: Got it.

GRAHAM DARBY: They then take the
measurements over onto a
modern jig.
And then we'll make it.

So you'll start with
the side beams.

Then you'll do the
cross-members.
Then you make the floor plans.
Then you make the uprights.

Then you make the
wheel arches.

And all of it's done by
millimeter precision.
DB4 convertible here.

Again, you can see that at
some point, somebody just

started to put a power hood in
it and cut the chassis out.

That's the main support
for the rear end.

That's the condition
of the tin worm.
JF MUSIAL: Oh man.

GRAHAM DARBY: So again, we'll
do something very
similar with that.

JF MUSIAL: That's such a
weird thing to see, to
see in a raw form.

Like, I've seen them painted,
but to see them with nothing
in it, it's almost surreal.

GRAHAM DARBY: Yeah, and you can
see here with the chassis,

every single part of the chassis
that was bent or

corroded that we couldn't
straighten,
we cut out and replaced.

But we only replace
what we have to.

So that trailing knob is not
new, but the back end and the
cross-members down there are.

So that's exactly what
we're saying.

We'll only replace what
we have to replace.

As you see, this is the original
body gut, where the
cars are made from new.

JF MUSIAL: And he just
hand-beats it.

GRAHAM DARBY: Hand-beats
it or rolls it.

But you can see here where all
the different panels are

brought together, including
up to the bulkhead.

JF MUSIAL: But it's almost safe
to say that not every DB5

or any process like this,
they're not always identical.
They're a little off.

GRAHAM DARBY: None of
them are identical.
None of them.

Part of this is, as you can
see, you've always got the

overlap, so that's where
the engine bay is.
So that will be folded in.

That's where you're going to
have the scuttle panel.

You always overcut it, so you
can fit it in to the vehicle.
JF MUSIAL: Got it.

GRAHAM DARBY: It's not like a
modern car where you can buy a

new panel of the shelf
and just bolt it in.
JF MUSIAL: It just fits in.

GRAHAM DARBY: Doesn't
work like that.
It never has done.

It was only when the original
Vanquish was built that you

actually had-- the first time
Aston Martin had body panels
that were interchangeable.
Before that, it was this.
And we work very hard.

Especially Kingsley has worked
very, very hard to develop

this business over the
last 30 years.
JF MUSIAL: It shows.

GRAHAM DARBY: And this
is the final stage of
the operational side.

So this is the heritage
workshop, which we're nigh on
finished on.

You've got a 1925 car
here that we look
after for the owner.

Been in a museum for about
seven, eight years.

Owner says he wants
to now drive it.

So he brought it in,
got it started.

Now we fix where the water
leaks, the oil leaks, the
typical leaks.

JF MUSIAL: Typical
things, yeah.
GRAHAM DARBY: Interesting one.
JF MUSIAL: Yeah?

GRAHAM DARBY: DB4 Mark V. So
this is the last of the DB4s
before the DB5 started.
You saw the body for the DB2?
JF MUSIAL: This is it.

GRAHAM DARBY: This
is the chassis.
JF MUSIAL: Cool!

GRAHAM DARBY: So David's
stripped the car.

David's putting it
back together.
Hundreds of man-hours on it.

But the owner comes from the
Far East, so we've also

modified it to fit
air conditioning.

JF MUSIAL: So that's
another question.

How far will you go in terms of
changing the existing car?

GRAHAM DARBY: Whatever
the owner wants.
JF MUSIAL: OK.
So if he wanted--

GRAHAM DARBY: It's
their choice.
It's their car.

JF MUSIAL: You've got
drum brakes on this.

So if you wanted to switch
it over to disk brakes--

GRAHAM DARBY: He could
have it if he wants.

JF MUSIAL: He would want--
you could do that.
GRAHAM DARBY: If he wanted to.

JF MUSIAL: Now, but how far
would you go in terms of not
allowing certain things?

GRAHAM DARBY: Well, it's not
our choice to not allow.

JF MUSIAL: Well, in
the sense that--

GRAHAM DARBY: We would
advise and discuss.
JF MUSIAL: OK.

GRAHAM DARBY: If somebody turned
around and said they

wanted a modern AP braking
system on a DB2, we may well

turn around and say we're not
sure that's going to work.

But no, it's the customer's
choice.
JF MUSIAL: OK.

GRAHAM DARBY: So he's got
an alternator now.

So he's got a modern
charging system.
He's got air conditioning.

Everything is being stripped,
powder coated,
replaced where necessary.

All the wiring looms
are built in-house.

So we make all new wiring
looms to the car.

Chassis has been
powder coated.

New fuel lines, new brake
lines, new fuel tank,
original fuel pump.

The [INAUDIBLE] also having
power steering.
So he's having E-STEER--
electronic power steering.
JF MUSIAL: Cool.

GRAHAM DARBY: And, again, a lot
of the purists will say
you can't do this.
Do you know what?

If he wants to drive the car
every single day, because he
can, why not?
DB3S.
JF MUSIAL: Awesome.

GRAHAM DARBY: This car
came into us from a
relatively new owner.

Came in for us to check it over,
didn't think there was a

huge amount wrong with it, but
actually, there was a lot of

corrosion and some poor
repairs that had
happened in its life.

So we've had to replace the
main tubes on the chassis.

And then the customer who
intends to race it has asked
us to rebody it.
So we've built him a new body.
JF MUSIAL: Whoa.

GRAHAM DARBY: The original
body we still hold.

And he'll have that
back at the end.

So he has a spare body
for the car.
JF MUSIAL: Just in case.

GRAHAM DARBY: We've also-- the
Tonneau cover, when it came

in, it was a leather one.
we've now put it back to
original factory
specifications, which were aluminum.

Obviously, this car had two
doors, which they were never
designed with.

They only had one door, so we
put it back to original
specification.

JF MUSIAL: You know, you've got
people who can literally
go anywhere in the world.

GRAHAM DARBY: Yes,
very much so.
And we have done.

JF MUSIAL: So explain
that process.
Someone calls up and--

GRAHAM DARBY: If we have a
customer or an individual who

has a vehicle where we don't
have a dealer partner to

assist, and obviously there's
certain parts of the world

where there aren't dealer
partners, they can either go

to their local dealer partner,
whether it's on that continent

or not, or they can
contact us.

We'll put together a price
for what it's going to
take to do the work.

And then we'll fly
our technicians
wherever it needs to be.

JF MUSIAL: So are those
technicians flying with their

own tools and the equipment
that they would need?
Or would they go--

GRAHAM DARBY: All we ask for
is an equipped workshop.
JF MUSIAL: Got it.

GRAHAM DARBY: So a RAM
extraction, lifting tools, and
equipment, and so on.

Then the rest of it, the guys
will ship their hand tools.
JF MUSIAL: Fantastic.

GRAHAM DARBY: Yeah,
very much so.

And whether that's body work
as well, so if we've got

somebody who's had a car that's
been heavily damaged

and we need to send some of
our panel technicians out

there to cut out the damaged
panels and bond a new one,
we've done that as well.

So yeah, we try and offer as
much flexibility as we can.

We love showing people
what we have here.

It's unique, and
it's beautiful.

And we're very proud
of what we've done.
JF MUSIAL: That's nice.

GRAHAM DARBY: And the reason
Aston Martin's still going

after 100 years is because of
the passion of the people that

work for it and the passion
of the owners that have
purchased the cars.
JF MUSIAL: Fantastic.

GRAHAM DARBY: It wouldn't
exist otherwise.

title: Aston Martin Works: Keeping the Legacy Alive - /DRIVEN
